issues.description: The problem statement and template expect a Rideable.messageOnRide() method with no parameters (returns String). The solution repository defines Rideable.messageOnRide(int speed) and implements Pig.messageOnRide(int) and Seal.messageOnRide(int), changing both the method signature and the expected output (they include "at [speed] mph"). This parameter mismatch prevents students from implementing code that matches the provided template/Main usage (which calls r.messageOnRide() with no argument) and the UML/specification in the problem statement.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the Rideable API across artifacts. Either (A) change the solution to match the problem/template by defining Rideable.messageOnRide() with no parameters and update Pig and Seal to implement messageOnRide() returning "Riding on [Animal Type] [name]" (remove the speed parameter and the "at [speed] mph" text), or (B) if an intended feature is to include speed, update the problem statement and template/Main to declare and call messageOnRide(int speed) (including updating examples and UML). Option A is recommended to preserve the current exercise specification and the Main/template usage.

issues.description: The problem statement and template expect a no-argument method messageOnRide() returning a String (UML and Part 2 specification) and the template's Main() calls r.messageOnRide() with no parameters. The solution, however, defines the Rideable interface and implementations with a different signature messageOnRide(int speed). This changes the conceptual contract of the Rideable behavior (introduces a speed parameter and alters the return formatting), creating a direct mismatch between the exercise description/template usage and the reference implementation. Students will be confused which API to implement and may face compilation/test failures because the template calls the no-arg version while the solution requires an int parameter.
issues.suggested_fix:
Make the contract consistent across artifacts. Either:
1) Align the solution with the problem/template: change Rideable.messageOnRide(int speed) to messageOnRide() (no arguments) and update Pig/Seal implementations to return the string format described in the problem ("Riding on [Animal Type] [name]"). This keeps the exercise as specified and matches the template Main() usage. Or
2) Align the problem and template with the solution: update the problem specification and template code to declare and call messageOnRide(int speed) and explicitly document the expected returned string (e.g., "Riding on [Animal Type] [name] at [speed] mph").
Recommended: apply option (1) so the reference solution matches the exercise text and the provided template code.
